description: From Middle English broun, from Old English brūn (“brown; dark; dusky”), from Proto-West Germanic *brūn, from Proto-Germanic *brūnaz, from Proto-Indo-European *bʰerH-. Doublet of bruin.

adjectives.description: brown (comparative browner or more brown, superlative brownest or most brown)

definitionGroups.group: (sometimes capitalized) Of or relating to any of various ethnic groups having dark pigmentation of the skin.

entries.meaning: (countable and uncountable) A colour like that of chocolate or coffee.
examples: The browns and greens in this painting give it a nice woodsy feel.

entries.meaning: (snooker, countable) One of the colour balls used in snooker, with a value of 4 points.

examples: I know there are many persons — some who are themselves poor — who 'never turn a beggar from their door,' but always give them a few browns (halfpence) or some scran (broken victuals).

entries.meaning: A brown horse or other animal.
(sometimes capitalised, countable, informal) A person of Latino, Middle Eastern or South Asian descent; a brown-skinned person; someone of mulatto or biracial appearance.
examples: Many browns and blacks are immigrants — some of whom have not yet become naturalized citizens of the United States.

entries.meaning: (entomology) Any of various nymphalid butterflies of subfamily Satyrinae (formerly the family Satyridae).
(entomology) Any of certain species of nymphalid butterflies of subfamily Satyrinae, such as those of the genera Heteronympha and Melanitis.
(hunting, as "the brown") A mass of birds or animals that may be indiscriminately fired at.
examples: The temptation to have a shot into the brown was great. There was not a head there which was not a big one and the one by himself was not too easy a shot since it is always difficult to shoot when lying in soft snow.

verbs.description: brown (third-person singular simple present browns, present participle browning, simple past and past participle browned)

examples: Synonyms: (chiefly literary and poetic) embrown, brownify
Fry the onions until they brown.

entries.meaning: (cooking, transitive) To cook something until it becomes brown.
examples: Pound an onion, warm a spoonful of ghee and throw in the onion, brown it slightly, add your curry stuff, brown this till it smells pleasantly,  […]
Light-skinned people tend to brown when exposed to the sun.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give a bright brown colour to, as to gun barrels, by forming a thin coating of oxide on their surface.
(demography, transitive, intransitive, slang, ethnic slur, usually derogatory, offensive) To turn progressively more Hispanic or Latino, in the context of the population of a geographic region.
